results.title: Abakanowicz in Australia
results.creator_credit: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Polish artist Magdalena Abakanowicz prepares for an exhibition of her work in Australia. We see her exhibits of large rope, hessian and string three-dimensional forms. She comments upon her intended purpose in working with such materials. Narrated by Margaret Throsby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McGill, Malcolm Otton, Crafts Council of Australia and Film Australia

results.title: AB: Year 11
results.brief_description: An anonymous digital dairy created by a young person as part of a day long workshop run by ACMI. Each diary is scripted and a voiceover recorded by the individual young person. Some diaries use photographs brought in by the participant, but the primary visual content is often black and white, ‘stock’ footage of a poetic nature. At no point should the creator or school be positively identified when screening this work.

results.title: Aardman classics
results.creator_credit: David Sproxton, Steve Box, Peter Lord, Nick Park and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description: Compilation of early Aardman short works, ranging from 1978-1999. Aardman, the animation studio specialising in claymation, are renowned for their humour, especially in relation to the portrayal of animals. Highlights here include “Pib and Pog” and “My baby just cares for me”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Sproxton, Steve Box, Peter Lord, Nick Park and Aardman Animations

results.title: Aardman animations. Vol. 01
results.creator_credit: Nick Park, Stephen Johnson, David Sproxton, Peter Lord, Barry Purves, Richard Goleszowski and Aardman Animations
results.brief_description: David Sproxton and Peter Lord began making films together at school, and in 1972 set up Aardman Animations in Bristol, specialising in model animation and claymation. This selection from the studio includes “Barefootin’”, an early pop-promo with a track by Robert Parker; “Next”, a witty 5 minute condensation of the entire Shakespearean theatrical canon; “Late Edition”, a warts-and-all look at a “right-on” newspaper; “My Baby Just Cares for Me”, a feline interpretation of the Nina Simone song; “Sledgehammer”, the celebrated Peter Gabriel clip; and the 1991 Academy Award winning interviews-at-the-zoo, “Creature Comforts” plus its highly successful follow-on, the Heat Electric TV commercials.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick Park, Stephen Johnson, David Sproxton, Peter Lord, Barry Purves, Richard Goleszowski and Aardman Animations

results.title: A.S. Neill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doubts and Certainties”.
An interview with A. S. Neil, headmaster of the pioneer school of Summerhill in Suffolk for fifty years. Here he discusses Hunkin and his belief that education must not be indoctrination and that the child’s emotions should be completely free.

results.title: A.I. Artificial intelligence
results.creator_credit: Steven Spielberg, Bonnie Curtis, Kathleen Kennedy, NBCUniversal and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A.I. is the story of David, a cyber boy, realistically designed and programmed to provide unconditional love to its owner. He enters the home of Monica and David, where Monica, after initial problems, embraces his presence… until their biological son returns.

constellations_other.name: 9.5mm Pathe-Baby and parents behaving badly
constellations_other.description: A look at the link between the Pathé-Baby system and animation, as well as the relationship between cinematic parents and their children.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Steven Spielberg, Bonnie Curtis, Kathleen Kennedy, NBCUniversal and Warner Bros Pictures
results.description: Intending “A.I.” as a collaboration between himself and Steven Spielberg, Stanley Kubrick created various treatments and hundreds of storyboards for the film - upon Kubrick’s death Spielberg inherited the project as director and co-producer. “A.I.” is the story of David, a cyber boy, realistically designed and programmed to provide unconditional love to its owner. David enters the home of Monica and David, where Monica, after initial problems, embraces his presence. Trouble brews however when Martin (the couple’s biological son, recovering from an illness) returns home and displaces David. David is turned out into the wilderness where he meets Gigolo Joe, a love robot on the run. Joe and David visit Rouge City, in search of the Blue Fairy (whom David is convinced will grant him mortality) and then to a Flesh Fair where the two witness a carnival of robot torture. “A.I.” is a fantastical quest that depicts a robot yearning to be real and hence loved, themes echoed in “Pinocchio” (a touchstone in the film) and “Blade runner.” A film with three quite distinct acts, “A.I.” is saturated with memorable images, set pieces and costumes, as well as some interesting concepts and ethical moral dilemmas but is compromised by its eagerness to provide David with a happy ending.
description_for_label: Intending “A.I.” as a collaboration between himself and Steven Spielberg, Stanley Kubrick created various treatments and hundreds of storyboards for the film - upon Kubrick’s death Spielberg inherited the project as director and co-producer. “A.I.” is the story of David, a cyber boy, realistically designed and programmed to provide unconditional love to its owner. David enters the home of Monica and David, where Monica, after initial problems, embraces his presence. Trouble brews however when Martin (the couple’s biological son, recovering from an illness) returns home and displaces David. David is turned out into the wilderness where he meets Gigolo Joe, a love robot on the run. Joe and David visit Rouge City, in search of the Blue Fairy (whom David is convinced will grant him mortality) and then to a Flesh Fair where the two witness a carnival of robot torture. “A.I.” is a fantastical quest that depicts a robot yearning to be real and hence loved, themes echoed in “Pinocchio” (a touchstone in the film) and “Blade runner.” A film with three quite distinct acts, “A.I.” is saturated with memorable images, set pieces and costumes, as well as some interesting concepts and ethical moral dilemmas but is compromised by its eagerness to provide David with a happy ending.

results.title: A.D. Hope
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
A D Hope talks in this entertaining interview of his childhood and its influence on his poetry, and the conflict with his life as a critic and academic.

results.title: A Zoo in the trees. - [2nd ed.]
results.creator_credit: Louise Jonas, Rob McCubbin and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: This program deals with the importance of forest preservation in all parts of the world as they are the life support systems for tree dwelling animals. By saving the trees we are also savings the various species which inhabit them. Groups of monkeys, apes and primative lemurs at the Royal Melbourne Zoo are intimately observed feeding, caring for their young, grooming and communicating with each other. These primates are contrasted with Australia’s tree dwelling animals - the koala, lace monitor, the grey- headed fruit bat and the green tree frog. Photographed by Frank Few and Rob McCubbin, edited by Robert Martin, script by Maree Teychenne, narrated by Desley Blanch, sound editing by David Hughes.
